review_title: Great company, inconsistent consulting career prospects for experienced hires
job_title: Management Consulting Senior Consultant in Singapore
pros:
- The structure and opportunity to learn to be effective and efficient while honing a driven mindset. 
- Great global network - there is always someone somewhere is the company that can help you with your topic at hand.
- Great learning place for program design and project management
- Sometimes opportunities to work on great projects that are high on the clients' agenda
cons:
- Personal growth relying heavily on getting the right sponsors. Very tough for experienced hires. 
- Promotion process : Merit : 40%, Politics : 60%
- The "sexiness" of the projects varies a lot in consulting at Accenture. For a few strategic projects there are many roles very operational, especially for those that are not in the strategy practice. 
- Lower salary that other top-tier consulting firms

pros: its alright but not great
cons: work can get quite boring

pros: Cutting-edge innovation, international projects, great client portfolio
cons: Work life balance can be improved, as for all consulting firms

pros: Good management and they value ppl

job_title: Senior Business Analyst/Senior SAP Consultant in Singapore
pros: Good place to learn, great people
cons: Usual problems that all big consulting companies may face

pros: lots to learn, opportunities to try different things
cons: Working hours are extensive, politics, OT is expected of you

review_title: Slave driver work culture,  No work life balance
pros: High Pay, High performance company
cons: Horrible work scheduling, Cut throat management. Regular mass firing phase for those new hire who require assistance and KT

pros: Good benefits and salary wise was fair.
cons: Sad to say when you don't have a project anymore they will let you go and won't find a new project.

pros: Great platform and great networking company
cons: Don’t have cons, overall a great experienced working in Accenture

cons: The documentation process is lengthy

review_title: Getting insulted for everything you do
pros: None whatsoever, the cons outweigh the pros
cons: Getting insulted on a regular basis and demoralizing to work at all

review_title: Good place to start off a career, bad place if u want work life balance
pros:
- Dedicated and friendly young people
- Managers are encouraging and willing to teach
- Great exposure - different roles and industry for projects
- Great corporate culture
cons:
- Crazy working hours
- Promotions sometimes is dependant on the months at level, in which affecting the actual promotion for the people who really put in effort.
- For the amount of hours u put in, around 60 hrs per week - the amount of pay that you are getting is nuts.

review_title: Good learning ground, but not a healthy environment to stay in
pros:
- Very flexible working styles; no one judges you based on the time spent in the office but rather on the quality and delivery of your work (WFH policy is widely used) 
- Awesome colleagues who are smart and talented, making work a lot more enjoyable
- Good opportunities for learning and growth, as long as you are up for the challenge
cons:
- Performance Management process (or what is known as Performance Achievement) allows for plenty of room for bias and favouritism. You often hear people saying that you need a good career counsellor who can represent you well enough in performance discussions to ensure your promotions. Some MDs are also very prone to bias, favouring some individuals over others (even when the impact doesn't add up). 
- Management talks a lot of "fluff" and is even sometimes hypocritical to a certain extent. For example, there is a lot of talk about being mindful and respectful to one another but yet we have MDs who are hollering down people and treating people like they have no feelings.

review_title: Good exposure, great colleagues, bad work life balance
pros: Good exposure, great colleagues. I meet some of the smartest and most competent friends in the company. IT-savvy folks who can laugh and joke despite demanding timeline and stress. Colleagues who work hard, and play harder. Camaraderie is strong. For people who likes to challenge themselves, know their own potential, and is ready to take on larger role than what most company will offer them based on age, gender, years of experience, you should truly consider Accenture. Accenture has a culture of putting people in position base on capability and not the other social factors.
cons: Accenture pays average salary. Despite the seemingly high monthly remuneration, the package doesn't include 13 month bonus. In terms of performance bonus, very top performer gets less than 2 months. Also, given the demanding nature of work, be prepared to sacrifice personal time. I have experienced working 6 days a week for more than 7 months straight. And there are a few occasion I had to work 30 days a month. Be warned.

review_title: Great company! But painful at times
pros: Fantastic people, everyone is smart and hard working and easy to work with. Managers are usually very good at helping guide your career and have your back.
cons:
Projects can be mixed either very exciting or very boring, or no project at all! Not the best holiday or health benefits. Also the organization is so big that it makes things very difficult to get anything done. Accenture moves very slowly when it comes to innovation and even selling in new projects. Things take forever to get approved and to work out kinks because there are so many people involved in every decision.

There are also so many people that communications are often in silos. You have one team talking to the same client as another team. And instead of knowing about each other and finding synergies to develop bigger projects, we work in silos and often miss out on bigger opportunities.

review_title: Can't believe I bought into the lie for 7 long years
pros:
Many project and learning opportunities which are great at the beginning of your career. 
Suck up to the right partner, be in the same project with the fat cats and you rise really quickly
cons:
Full of young people who work long hard hours but with little experience nor quality
Sheer numbers without considering quality of hiring, no proud branding any longer
Promotion/progression based on WHO you know, rather than performance
Glass ceiling due to organisation pyramid, everyone's stuck. So they sell lies and empty promises.
People take on dual roles, "vertical"/"parallel" roles as an excuse to groom or see your potential, which are blatant all lies. It is to save cost...no, make more money for the fat cats in management.
Many badly sold projects by senior management and many good men and women are sent on "suicide missions" to deliver rubbish timelines and scope.

pros:
Great working opportunities. 
Able to learn many things in the challenging environment. 
Some managers/ senior managers are very helpful and open to new ideas and suggestions.
cons:
Very bad work life balance. If you do not work during weekends, you wont be able to fit into the team culture. 
For some MDs or Senior managers, you have to bootlick them to get your things done. 
Very self centered environment. Seniors will not help and you are not allowed to ask questions after your probation period. 
Those who work longer expect you to work like them so that you as a newcomer will not tarnish the team reputation. 
Political environment as well. Have to be really careful with the usage of words in your emails and conversations as they will use the words in the content to attack you. 
When upper management email during wee hours, you have to reply 5-10 minutes in order to make them feel that you are working hard and not sitting on their emails even though the KPI is 2 business days. 
Usually bosses do not know what their subordinates are doing as they only listen to seniors to provide feedback.

pros: Good salary and good people
cons: Long hours everyday and most weekends

review_title: Good learning experience, but would not work there again.
pros: Total pay is relatively good, although when broken down per actual hour worked it is rather low. Health benefits are good. Employment with Accenture also looks good on the resume.
cons:
Competence levels of those in management are inconsistent. The top-financed projects have strong leadership and good planning, and as a consequence the employees work in a pleasant environment with relatively decent hours. Most other projects tend to fall behind schedule, and employees will have to work long hours with no compensation to ward off disaster. Entry level employees should expect to be assigned to one of the latter projects. 
Bonus compensation is almost negligible; thus total compensation is far worse than it appears at first glance. 
Turnover is very high.

pros: Once hired, you get to attend a lot of good corporate parties in fancy hotels.As long as we do our job well , we do not have to worry about losing it.
cons: Worked for a client whom I directly reported to and the client submitted great reviews about me. I had no Accenture side manager who had any idea of the kind of technical work that I did for the client. When it was time for my promotion cycle, I had to go on maternity leave , and I got to know later that due to some internal politics they gave preference to some other candidates whose rating was lower than mine under the assumption that I may decide to extend my maternity leave and may not come back after its completion.Also they completely ignored the positive reviews provided by the client and I had to call them up on a weekend to remind them to put the positive feedback in my appraisal as they were unaware of the work I had done as they have never been to my client workplace.

review_title: Great company to build a strong foundation for a professional career.
pros:
Great place to kick start a career
Opportunity to build invaluable foundational skills, which would very useful in any organisation
Great exposure to network with senior management clients and within Accenture
Great place to make great friends, particularly colleagues at similar levels, as everyone have gone through the same ups and downs
Lots of drinking and social networking opportunities
Good travel opportunities 
Good Training opportunities
cons:
Horrendous working hours
Unappreciative bosses
Slave drivers
Steep Learning Curve
Salary works out to be uncompetitive, considering the long hours 
Poor work life balance
Projects budget and resources tend to be underestimated, leading to very tight delivery timelines and having to sacrifice work quality
Very target driven, at times sacrificing work quality and employee welfare
Difficult to take time off for training or personal breaks, given project commitments and timelines

pros:
1. Good learning, in terms of functional, communication skills.
2. Work with very smart and responsible group of people
3. Good e-learning system
cons:
1. Promotion doesn't happen because of your deep skills or outstanding contribution, but who you know and who stands up to fight for what you deserve. Rating is done when they try to compare apple vs orange, on unfair basis. It's 90% luck, 10% capability. Too much politics in the process.
2. Very pragmatic business model, you will be redundant anytime.
3. Long hours, low compensation per hour, bonus is not good.

pros:
1) Strong people to learn from and build your expertise / soft skills
2) Fairly stable pipeline of work where client engages us to for more delivery work 
3) Able to learn from different tracks of work e.g. picking up business and technical skills
cons:
1) Work-life balance does not exist (basically out-of-scope) and expected to deliver on tight timelines
2) Certain projects hire from a certain set of people which may not have the required skill sets :)
3) Efforts not as recognized where OT is common and you could even do overnight / weekends e.g. "this is your job / the nature of this industry"

pros: Great team, fun people, reasonable work-life balance for a consultancy, and fairly interesting projects for Accenture Strategy. I've had a lot of fun and opportunity to travel for work (though that's a double-edged sword as much as it sounds like a dream). Reasonable opportunities and great flexibility at work (working from home here and there, showing up super late, etc., as long as your work is done)
cons:
Lacking brand name, but that's in progress! 
Missing resources to do the job sometimes, such as specialised databases and research
Office equipment could be better to facilitate work, such as better laptops and screens, etc.
Underpaid relative to competitors at junior levels. Gets better as you progress.
Bonus and increments can be a little underwhelming.
I feel there's some lack of diversity in the senior management.

pros: Being a multinational corporation, it is vast. The interview, online examination, and orientation is standardized. As an employee, you have the chance to be assigned to at least one project depending on your skillset, and might also have the chance to travel onshore as part of the project's requirements in order to complete the tasks-at-hand. It is quite strict in terms of enforcing policies in order to make sure that data is kept safe and secure. The benefits are good, especially medical since the entire family can be covered for medical procedures and hospitalization.
cons: There are some projects that strictly enforce different processes, while other projects are more lenient. Also, one should have the mindset and self-discipline and motivation to progress in order to maximize different opportunities, otherwise one can be stuck at the same task.

pros: What I enjoyed most working here are the colleagues who are friendly, kind and helpful. There is strong mentorship / career counselling programme where your voice would be heard and there would be people help you with challenges / difficulties in the firm. Lots of perks - typical for a consulting firm -  but lots of hard work to pay that off as well :)
cons:
You need to strive to protect your work-life balance. As a fresh grad, this might seem hard to achieve but there is always ways to balance between work and social life - just need to learn how. 
You might not get the most desirable project / position that you would like to work in. But there are always people who would listen to you - career counsellor and help you to find a better suited position.

review_title: Solid candidate experience, horrid employee experience.
pros: Strong knowledge and learning culture, for better or worse. Either you’re thrown into the deep end to fend for yourself.. or you sink out.

review_title: Lots of toxic people, learning opportunities are limited
pros:
Salary is good for fresh grad
Free drinks at level 31
Central location if you’re based in rct
cons:
Colleagues are mostly toxic, competitive, know little and only concerned with sucking up
Strange hr practices / high hr turnover rate (a few months after you joined, the hr who hired you had already resigned)
Not a collaborative environment because everyone is overly concerned about their own promotions and trying too hard to please the managers
Colleagues also seem to think that technical skills are not important (please don’t be a joke, why are you even in Accenture)
Learning opportunities depend on whether the manager likes you or not and whether he or she wants to give you opportunities to work on projects
Join if you intend to be stuck for a few years because you can’t really job hop without any skillset and no other company will pay you this amount due to your lack of skillset

pros:
- Good brand name that looks good on your CV.
- Knowledgable colleagues who are willing to share information (knowledge transfer)
- Slightly higher compensation package for fresh grads (contractor basis)
cons:
- Long working hours ( average 12 hours per day) and sometimes need to come back on the weekend. (Depends largely on the nature of the project)

 - As a contractor, we are not given many opportunities to progress in our career. There are lack of training opportunities (in some projects, none at all) given to improve on our skillsets. 

-  It is very tough for a contractor to be converted as a permanent employee even if the person is performing above average. The usual reason given is lack of headcount.

pros:
- You tend to feel challenged at work.
- If you are good performer, you tend to be given more opportunity to do more and learn more to the point that it way exceed your pay grade.
- People are nice and fun here.
cons:
- Profit driven mentality leadership that willing to compromise quality to get this done.
- Lack of mentorship. People with many years of experience unwilling to coach and want fresh grad to run the show
- Compensation package is not as attractive as other firm.
- Work life balance is subjective on the state of the project which frequently isnt balanced.
- 15 days leave only? Come on

review_title: Great if you are able to navigate and adapt
pros:
- People are always there for you, even if you've never met them before or they're in a different office
- Colleagues are generally fun to work with 
- There are always opportunities to take up more responsibility
- If you can navigate the organization, you have a lot of flexibility and autonomy in your work
- Strong growth and great focus on the future
cons:
- It's hard to navigate the politics of the organization, and that will lead to you having great roles versus tedious and boring roles
- It's easy to get trapped into a specialization that you aren't passionate about
- There's always that unintelligent and overbearing manager that you have to work under

pros:
-many things to learn
-transport allowance
-lifestyle allowance more flexible than flexi points
cons:
-No 13 month
-although you have many things to learn, ALL THE TIME, you are force to learn these skills on your own. NO DEDICATED training of whatsoever. Mangers will upsell you to the clients (say you are a pro even though you just pick it up last week etc.)
-Analyst are like dust, if you are not up for the job, they can replace you anytime
-All managers care about are sales (and most of them cant code but expect you to know how to, else you are useless [in tech])
-No preference of the projects you want to be staff in (ie. they throw you where they need ppl and expect you to pick up whatever knowledge that is required)
-needless to say, looonnngggg working hours
-All in all no company culture. you are there just to be useful.

review_title: Good place to start a career, but hard work required
pros: Structured training ensures that you know what is expected of you, and due to the demanding nature of most project, you get to learn many things very quickly, as long as you can keep up with the pace. Good brand name to put onto your resume, especially for subsequent moves either to Business schools or to other firms. Great reputation.
cons: Difficult to attain work life balance, at least in your first 2 years. Also, easy to get lost in such a huge firm, unless you are driven enough to plan and manage your own career growth. Professional growth very much dependent on project assigned, followed by personal merits.

pros:
Good place to start a career, environment that is helpful to learn to whoever is keen. Working with smart and like-minded people is enjoyable.
Experience in Accenture is great as employers look out for experienced consultants/managers from consulting firms, especially brand name ones like Accenture.
cons: Yearly banding cycles are non transparent and largely depend on who you know instead of what you actually do. The promotion and increment is based on who represents you in the banding session and how senior/good the person is representing you.

review_title: Accenture is a big Organization and a good place to work.
pros:
Easy going Organization
Good long term projects 
Work life balance
Lot of perks and non monetary benefits
Big pool of resources
cons:
Employee is treated as employee
Immediate reporting managers are not supportive
No clarity in promotion process, depends on employee manager relation not on work
HR is super poor and only rely on managers response and never check with the peers or client about the performance

review_title: Accenture at a Glance for a Software Engineer
pros: I can say that Accenture encourages its employees to constantly train and empower themselves through seminars and boot camps. The amount of work depends on the role and project you are in, so it varies. There are lots of opportunities available within the company, and it is up to the employee to chart his or her own career path. In terms of human resources and benefits, the company strives to provide its employees pain-free access to such resources through web-based applications.
cons: In my opinion, for performance ratings, competition can be tough yet there are programs that help employees perform better at work in order to raise performance rating. The performance rating is very important for it can delay a person's role promotion and salary raise.

pros: Great for fresh grads or career switch to gain more exposure
cons:
Delivery and ops team are always at the bottom of the command chain, basically being squeezed and shove into the face. No collaboration between 2 teams because of everybody get all defensive. 

Among ops team are also defensive against each other. Nobody has the time or patience to talk through things and be understanding. Hardworking people are taken for granted. 

Getting promotion is not based on your effort, more on how do you present yourself at the expense of your people. 

You will only get appreciated when you are leaving. On a regular basis, nobody bats an eye on your concerns. To the extend where you will be ignored. 

HR team is very not responsive at all. They don’t reply you and when they do, they will be rude when seek for HR matters. It sounds like as if you are asking them a stupid question.

pros: This is one of the best places for fresh grads and young people. You will learn A LOT - yes you will work VERY hard, but you will learn and gain so much. There is a lot of flexibility, and most ppl behave in a respectful and professional manner.
cons: It can't be help that there are always a few rotten apples, and the truth is they are usually 'old timers'.  My advice is just stay away from toxic ppl and focus on the good ones, there are PLENTY here.

pros:
A large organisation with offices and opportunities to work anywhere globally
A few excellent partners in the strategy practice are great to work with for their expertise and their ability to support and empower their team
cons:
Some partners in the strategy practice are mostly focused on their own career with little interest in their team members. With its complex and narrow-minded performance management system Accenture has created a culture of fear largely sustained by this leadership, holding back the potential of many employees on many front. This culture of fear not only slows the organisation and drives tremendous stress.

Some senior managers and partners - particularly true for the sustainability strategy practice - are just not properly qualified and experience for the job. A self-centered and patronizing attitude and a general lack of clarity and coherence are just a few explanations for its poor results to date.

review_title: Great Place to work if you know the right people
pros: Accenture is a great place to learn alot in a short time, exposure to leading clients and technology is yours for the taking
cons: Accenture has a habit of promising you one thing then doing another .. you base your career on guidance to get you to the next level only to find that that criteria has changed. Benefit package is a total joke especially if they continue with the plan of start prying into peoples personal information to get basic health coverage

review_title: High Performance. Delivered. The Accenture Way!
pros: Great network of project ideas for you to harness, grow and learn from the Accenture community. Great company culture to foster strongly knit internal collaboration and communications across the globe. In Accenture, you'll find that the greatest support are the people and their knowledge all encapsulated in a power point deck delivered via projects or client presentations! Somewhere, somehow, you'll find someone in another part of the world doing what you plan to embark on or having done something similar! So that's the resource you should reach out to in order to get some form of support or even to start a discussion regarding your new project. In Accenture, we work as a team!
cons: NO WORK LIFE BALANCE - ONLY WORK LIFE INTEGRATION. Grueling long hours due to client demands and the nature/culture of the firm in high performance delivered that can come at the expanse of the staff's health, personal life/space and happiness. It is very common to find burnt out individuals who would eventually leave their jobs within months or less than ONE year. Accenture really needs to work on inculcating work life balance values to their senior leadership that would then be cascaded down to the working levels from senior managers right down to the analyst level. Very lean resourcing to projects (typical make up of a Snr Mgr, Consultant & Analyst) managing enterprise level large scale delivery projects as well as BD work and sometimes / most times - sales pitches. If you're a coder, be prepared, you maybe asked to attend a client pitch session to sell something! Your work scope may not be exactly what you sign up for. However, it is up to the individual to take this on positively in their personal capacity as a form of learning opportunity. But for experienced hires, this can be rather daunting, to be tasked to do something that you've not been skilled in or sign up for. That is when you've to reevaluate the role.

job_title: Business and Technology Delivery Analyst in Singapore
pros: As a fresh graduate, coming to Accenture will be a great starting point. You are entrusted with tasks immediately and these tasks have great direct impact to the project itself. Depending on the project structure and team members, you may be in good hands or you will just have to learn how to swim on your own. Either way, you will get to learn a lot.
cons: It is difficult to get proper training hence going to a new project is like going to a brand new world of new challenges. Upper management decisions are hidden away from the employees so you will not know why you are compensated this way etc.

pros: Smart people who drive you to excellent results on a regular basis. Good salary, very good HR management. Lots of programmes that are designed to improve your skills retraining (for example, the company can pay for your advanced degree, as long as you commit to continuing to work at Accenture for a short period after your degree).
cons: Terrible work-life balance. The number of hours that you put in is not commensurate to your progress up the ladder (which depends a lot more on which "clique" you are part of)

review_title: Great place to start your career
pros:
- There are numbers of project with various roles offering (after completing one project, you can indicate your role preference on the next project e.g. developer, business analyst, functional designer etc), but it depends on the project demand
- Leadership is great. Management listens to your feedback and is approachable.
- Good exposure if you want to technology related-work and employees are generally nice
cons:
- Work life balance. Management most of the time will schedule tight deadline and need you to work over nights/weekends
- Benefit is average or below market pay.
- Sometimes hard to get vacation leave due to tight schedule

review_title: Looks great on your resume, will work you to the bone!
job_title: Talent and Organizational Performance in Singapore
pros:
You'll make some amazing contacts and good friends
The name looks great on your resume
You'll work with some high profile clients 
Great learning and development on the analyst and consultant level
cons:
You'll be worked to the bone - work/life balance doesn't exist especially when you're understaffed on projects. Be prepared to work all hours, at all times and don't complain! 
You'll be told - if you do well, you'll rise up quickly but that doesn't really happen because of the office politics and favoritism.

review_title: Good company to gain experience fast
pros: The massive amount of work that you are given trains you up to know how to prioritize your work and time. The wide array of roles within a project also allows one to pick up and learn more about a role and what it takes to complete an end to end project fast.
cons: Expect to work very hard, with little gratitude from the bosses, as you are expected to do so. Promotions and pay increment are getting more difficult to obtain, and they have generally been bad during the recent years.

pros:
- Had a chance to work with experience and great people
- Most of the time uses latest technology
cons:
- No work life balance
- Package below the market
- Bonus, promotion totally depends on the project and manager
- HR doesn't know what the resource is working for

job_title: Software Engineering Senior Analyst in Singapore
pros: Great exposure for new joiner and fresh graduate as he will be exposed to the latest technology and methodology. Everyone has lots of opportunity to learn even though he might not have work-life balance.
cons: Performance appraisal is based on luck. At the end of the financial year, each will be graded through a banding system whereby your reviewer and counsellor will present your performance at a banding meeting. In my opinion, the grading system is pretty much based on the project revenue and how well your reviewer/supervisor fight for you in the banding meeting as you are graded against peers from other projects also.  So, it pretty much depends on luck.

pros: Good peer group, smart people, conservative company, fair employee practices, good business model, brilliant people, good knowledge base, good place to grow for a go getter
cons: Not people friendly, does not look for people's strength and utilize it for self as well as company's growth, Poor people health cover for Singapore employees. Employees in US and Europe have better benefits.

review_title: If your work or career is your priority in life then this is the place to be
pros:
Structure is already setup. In non-delivery centers; acn is regarded as one of the places where people want to work in.
They pay their employees accdg to market.
cons:
No work life balance
Its a bit tough to grow if you have been assigned a not so good role
They ask you to work anytime of the day anytime of the week. On call all the time

review_title: Excellent learning ground for fresh grads
pros:
- global exposure
- good variety of projects
- competitive total package for a fresh graduate
- work with the best minds and talents
- supportive and a winning culture
- high performance delivered
cons:
- only for very driven individuals who are willing to trade-off personal time and adopt pure work mentality and after work socialise with colleagues
- varies project to project, daily input of 12 hours as the bare minimum, peak period 16 hours daily, weekends and public holidays may not be spared to meet deadlines

review_title: Good place to learn but not so good to earn
pros:
- One of the best place to work because of the people you get to work with
- Chances to explore on cutting edge technologies if you are able to seize the opportunity
- One of the best firm with Inclusion and Diversity programme
cons:
- Mid management skills need to be improved in terms of setting the team's expectation and comitting to reasonable delivery timelines.
- Reward and promotions should be given on time instead of waiting for the yearly performance review in order to retain talent.

review_title: High pressure, ability to get broad based experience and work with a lot of determined people. Good chance to develop.
pros: Leadership opportunities, and chance to get faster promotions (however look at cons). In addition, there is great exposure to multiple clients. Good chance to network with people.
cons: Work life balance is poor. Control over projects that you are assigned to is not great. Sometimes, training might be denied due to 'project budget' constraints. Tendency for the culture to force people to constantly 'stand out' as compared to 'get things done'.

pros: Perfect if you are wanting to begin a career in technology delivery as being a large organisation with a vast clientele, you will be able to hone your skills and specialise on an industry or technology of your choosing.
cons:
Typical in an IT consulting industry, you will be expected to work overtime without pay and compensation is on the low side due to the simple fact that they have to put a markup when selling your services to the client. 

Typical in a large organisation, standing out based on your performance alone will not get you very far. Navigating through politics and the occasional showboating required.

review_title: Hit and miss about your career depending on your assignment
pros: Great place to work if you're young and single and want to learn things quickly. The number of opportunities across the globe are plenty. If you're in Consulting, then your career progression is great.
cons: If you're outside Consulting, then it comes with a lot of limitations in terms of choice of work, pay can be low, working hours can be horrible, and you may need to work the weekends most of the time. You can get a call at midnight asking you to complete something within the next hour.

review_title: Unless you want to learn so many things in a short period of time...
pros:
1. a lot of work. A LOT.
2. good place to start if you are a fresh graduate
3. good place to start if you don't have any technical background but want to pick up technical skills.
4. Good benefits (medical benefits, professional magazines subscription, dental allowance etc.)
cons:
1. a lot of work.
2. no work life balance
3. high expectations

review_title: Great place to start your career and be among high performers
pros:

cons:

pros:
Extensive benefits
Accenture offers all full-time employee subsidised medical compansation up to 30% of their clinical visits, and subsidised dental consultant. Full-time employees are allowed to visit some tourist attractions for free. 

High degree of autonomy and job flexible
Everyone in the team is given a clear role in the project. They have been held accountable for their own actions, and they are allowed to work on the way they felt right. The company is on more of a 'Result-only work environment', when you can work at your own pace and timing, as long as you met the deadline. The company allow you to enter the company at your own timing as long as it's not overboard. I have worked with developers who only came into work after lunch.
cons:
No sense of purpose
There is no sense of purpose working in the company. One of the company motto is '
Client Value Creation'. From my understanding Client Value Creation is to advise the client on what is the best for them, and not blindly follow what the clients, and in the end, let the clients suffer with a lousy product. 

Unattainable goals
More often, the project manager sets unrealistic deadline for almost every aspects of the project. At the first start of the project planning, the management has already planned 10 (+/- 1) hours of workload to be completed in a workday, which allowed them to complete the project on-time. With such unattainable goal-setting, employees had to often finding them working overtime daily. 

Unfair pay compensation
More than often, more than half of the employees work overtime more than 40% of their regular working hours for extended period of more than two months annually. There is no overtime pay for all additional hour put in. In additional, the management is not at all appreciative of the employees' overtime effort, instead, the management sees it as a complusory free labour. 

When comparing the pay structure of the project, almost half of the employees are being paid below the market rate. 

Closed-minded management
Whenever the management encountered problem, they will seek advice from the employees. However, the management will more than often not take the advice, and made their own decision. This make the feedback irrelevant, and slowly, the employee stop giving feedback, as they knew that their feedback will not be taken by the management.

pros: Decent benefits, significant number of long term clients and projects, attractive career progression, good team work among co-workers especially those that have worked in the firm for a long time
cons: Salary increment has slowed down tremendously over the years, upper level management tend to focus more of winning work with small budgets which ends up burning out the employees. Doesn't seem to treasure employees with deeper technical skills. High attrition rate

pros: As the company is recognized worldwide, employees from accenture are highly regarded in the industry. Accenture is known to be highly selective of its people, therefore the team members and colleagues you interact with on daily basis is of high caliber.
cons: Working at accenture almost always involves long working hour and high stress level. Weekend work is hardly norm-defying. These factors contribute to the high employee turnover rate.

The is the best way to retain talent and intellectual property.

Ridiculously long working hours, especially if you are working for the government clients. review_title: Many opportunities to learn, some opportunities for growth, lots depends on projects
pros:
Accenture is a great place for you to to learn. The breath and depth of projects that you can be on exposes you to many different technologies, capabilities, and project implementation methodologies (Agile, Waterfall, 'Watergile', Kanban). I've done several projects in the IT advisory space and have appreciate the learning experience. In addition, there are always training opportunities available up for grabs.

Some Accenture folks also really know their stuff and are solid, competent advisors, but these can be far and few. If you find someone like that, stick with them and you will learn so much.

Networking as in other consulting firms is a must, and you do get to network with the leadership, etc. That's how I was able to get on the good projects.
cons:
It's political and YMMV depending on your projects. If you come in and get stuck on a large scale ERP project (SAP, Workday, etc) for 2 years, then it limits your growth (unless you want to do SAP, etc. , then its great). Project leads are reluctant to let you go unless you have another project that is willing to take you on.

If you are good, network, get to know folks, then you'll have many opportunities and projects and some can be really cutting edge and super interesting. If its training you want, you'll have to seek out those opportunities and ask for it - you'll likely get the trainings you want if you ask (cause most don't bother asking), but it does depend.

Promotions however really depends on your lead. If they like you, then you get promoted. If they don't, then its quite a lot harder. A lot of times the key leaders have all the say and can 'override' the promotion list. If you get to work closely with them, then all the more better 'cause you're on the top of their minds.

review_title: TOXIC Environment with a stench of Colonial mindset
pros:
If you enjoy traveling and the world.... in my 12 years, I think I must have travelled over 30 plus countries.

Good place to start your career (in the past)... now, not so much. Especially new analysts are asked to do mindless things such as preparing schedule excel and doing useless PMO work. REALLY DEPEND ON YOUR LUCK
cons:
Been in the firm for more than 12 years - from fresh analyst all the way to AD level. I have seen how the firm has regressed over the last 5 years especially with the departure of the old guards and the import of all the foreign talents from Europe. These SM and MD just typically stay for a couple of years before returning back. So there is really no people development.... its all about promoting their own people or to import more. 

- factionalism is so prevalent in the OG. U need to know which camp u are in 

- The firm reeks of favoritism. Your promotion depends on your faction and who you know. You can do so badly in a project but because you come from a particular country and the MD is your mentor - you can easily get away and get your promotion. 

- your typical bonus is less than 1 month. Yes LESS THAN 1 month for average performer.... now even if you are the top performer , you are just looking at 2.5 months. we are talking about 7 days a week - just working day and night...

- the firm no longer cares about doing the right thing for the client. Its more about how to do the minimum and get the hella out of the engagement. To Accenture, the completion of an engagement provides them with an opportunity to create credentials and sell more work to  new customers who buy into their bluff. 

- we hired so many new fresh smart graduates by selling them the idea that they will be working on the "new IT"... all the big buzz words such as machine learning, AI, cognitive learning.... but the truth is....we don't even have any of these projects, apart from some simple POC. These analysts are actually doing meaningless excel or ppt...which adds zero value to their career. 

- Accenture talks a lot on  core values but no longer practise it at all. Its no longer about client value or people developer... Its now all about numbers.... just close any deals, bluff your way through and throw the project to the delivery team. As for the people, doesn't matter what they are doing or learning...as long as they are chargeable. 

Its truly sad to see how Accenture has degraded to this stage.

job_title: Senior Manager in New York, NY
pros: I was a lateral senior hire from another firm into Accenture’s Strategy Consulting practice. And boy oh boy, I had no idea what a toxic place a work environment could be in todays times, and in the US, especially amongst supposedly well educated and composed folks. I was in for the rudest shock I have experienced in my 15 year career. The other ‘senior managers’ were rude, unwelcoming, abrupt, closeted and down right hostile. The partners to whom they had sworn their loyalty to, sheparded them, coddled, and ‘protected’ them, gave them the choicest billable roles, while I was the black unwanted sheep. It took a few months to realize, the toxic, inbred, incestuous culture was one of ‘BROWN NOSING YOUR WAY UP’ ! The way to cling to and climb the ladder was purely based on this one vital ability ! A lateral hire, though more qualified and creative, was a threat, to the insecure incestuous bunch. I was later told during my exit interview, ‘yes, it’s difficult to assimilate as a senior lateral hire !” !!! HA ! So, if you want to go jump into a toxic hole, then be my guest. To me, it was one of the worst experiences in my life ! Ever wonder where these genes came from ? Look just back to the deceptive ‘Anderson Consulting’ days….the Apple doesn’t fall far from the tree. And look for their breed implanted in other companies, which is traditional practice in consulting, for them to ferry and curry out consulting deals to their heathen !
cons: See pros above for your creative process to imagine what the cons could possibly be !

review_title: pros and cons working in accenture
pros: Benefits, joining bonus, wfh equipment, allowances
cons: Worst managers, HRs,Extra working hours more than10, project allocation and mainly the worst part is always we have to write assessments starting from the joining i.e technology training till stream training and also they give choice to select stream but they don’t allocate that stream we have to qualify each and every assesment in order to sustain the job like technology training given for 45 days after we have to qualify the assesment and after stream training will be given again we have to qualify 4 assessments if not u will be in danger and also job security is worst. They don’t even value ur words if deployed in right project then ok if not u will be over and also if u try to speak against them they will be threatening u like u will be facing several consequences like that.even allowances are not been given in project even though they been had.

review_title: They need to take more responsibility to give new hires real opportunities
pros: Smart people, good resources, great client base
cons: There isn't any time to learn on the job and everyone assumes you will know exactly what to do on day one, so be careful what level you come in at. Lower levels are safer because analysis work is pretty standard and managers and senior managers will give you templates and more guidance. Senior managers are basically screwed because managing directors don't have time to show them the ropes and the rest of the team is depending on them to already know how to do it a certain way the team is used to. When trying to get on projects, senior managers and managers will also find out that managing directors already have their favorite "go to" people they have worked with for years, so they will ONLY pick you if those people are unavailable. Because of the fast nature of everything, if you make one wrong misstep, it will be assumed it is because you are incompetent, not that you misunderstood the ask or something else was the cause.

pros: Used to be a great company to work for before all tech industries started going downhill. Great benefits, good culture, good severance package after being laid off (given a 6wk notice of the roll off (layoff) date, then given an additional 6wks pay after separating from the company.
cons: Laying people off via email knowing that we have multiple email accounts and only check one frequently. I've seen several coworkers receiving condolences about getting laid off from a coworker that assumed they already received notice of being laid off. Imagine how that could rock one's world. Laying off entire departments of people and never letting other departments know there's a downsizing going on. This leaves the handful of people who DO know in fear of losing their job and the bulk of people who DO NOT know oblivious to what's happening and the possibility of losing their job. Laying off your highest earning personnel and then reposting their exact same job for 20k less a year is insane.

pros: 1. Professional development: Accenture offers a wide range of training programs and resources to help employees develop their skills and advance their careers. The company also provides mentorship and coaching to support employees in achieving their goals. 2. Global opportunities: With offices in more than 120 countries, Accenture offers employees the opportunity to work with clients from around the world and gain valuable international experience. 3. Diversity and inclusion: Accenture is committed to creating an inclusive workplace that values diversity and fosters a culture of belonging. The company offers a range of employee resource groups (ERGs) to support underrepresented communities. 4. Social impact: Accenture is committed to making a positive impact in the communities where it operates. The company has a range of social impact programs and initiatives that allow employees to give back and make a difference. 5. Innovation: Accenture is at the forefront of innovation, helping clients transform their businesses through digital technologies and new ways of working. Working at Accenture provides the opportunity to work on cutting-edge projects and be part of the latest trends in technology and business. 6. Work-life balance: Accenture supports its employees in achieving a healthy work-life balance. The company offers flexible work arrangements, wellness programs, and a range of employee benefits to support the well-being of its employees. 7. Competitive compensation and benefits: Accenture offers competitive salaries, performance-based bonuses, and a range of benefits, including health and wellnes
cons: Long hours: Accenture is known for its demanding work environment, and employees may be required to work long hours to meet project deadlines or client demands. This can lead to work-life balance challenges and potential burnout.

review_title: Great Overall But Easy To Be Overworked
job_title: Business and Integration Arch Senior Analyst in Nashville, TN
pros: 100% Work from home --- Encourages constant learning / Great place to earn certifications --- Incredibly broad range of clients you can potentially work for --- Good place to build experience quickly --- Typical benefits --- Travel for work is possible
cons: Meeting the demands of both the client(s) and Accenture internally can put a strain on your work-life balance. They mean it when they say they encourage a healthy balance (not punished for setting boundaries), but your career progression will be quite slow unless you are overworking constantly. At least in regards to software developers, the pay is lower than you could receive elsewhere, especially if you have specialized knowledge and experience. Travel sometimes required / not optional

job_title: Junior Data Reviewer in Warsaw, Masovia
pros: -not a difficult job at all: no risks, anyone can do it; -reviewers (team members) are nice and friendly, and thanks to that the working atmosphere is enjoyable as long as the team leaders are not around; -flexibility with shifts (morning and evening); -the salary is not high, but if you have a language bonus it is ok, especially considering how stupid the job is; -Mybenefit platform, private insurance; -Polish language course for free.
cons: -you will need to lie about your job and what you're doing; - dull and repetitive job, you just need to do the same task over and over again; -team leaders are horrible, and they treat reviewers as numbers. Don't expect to learn anything from your team leaders, they are simply useless; - no possibilities to learn or develop new skills; -there is a time tracker- you need to plan all your activities based on it. Even going to the bathroom; team leaders are obsessed with the time tracker, and they will bother you if you have used 32 minutes of the Break code (instead of 30 min); -getting promoted is not related to your skills, personality, performance at the interview, etc: it is related to with whom you're hanging out in your free time. Choose wisely ;)

review_title: Opportunities for growth, but long hours expected
pros: Good work-life balance: Many employees praise Accenture for offering flexible schedules and a supportive work environment that allows for a healthy balance between work and personal life. Diverse and inclusive culture: Accenture is widely regarded as a diverse and inclusive workplace, with a supportive community of employees from different backgrounds and experiences. Opportunities for growth and development: Accenture is known for offering employees opportunities to take on new challenges, expand their skill sets and grow professionally. Competitive compensation and benefits: Many employees note that Accenture offers a comprehensive benefits package and competitive salaries, making it a desirable place to work. Emphasis on innovation and technology: As a leading technology consultancy, Accenture is at the forefront of innovation and invests heavily in cutting-edge technologies and tools.
cons: Long hours: Many employees note that Accenture can be demanding in terms of time and workload, with long hours and tight deadlines being common. High-pressure work environment: Accenture is a fast-paced workplace and employees are expected to deliver high-quality work under tight deadlines, which can lead to a high-pressure work environment. Bureaucracy and politics: Some employees mention that Accenture can be bureaucratic and politically charged, with a hierarchical structure that can make it difficult to get things done efficiently. Lack of job security: Some employees express concern about job security, as the consulting industry is known for being highly competitive and subject to economic fluctuations. Limited opportunities for advancement: While Accenture offers many opportunities for professional development and growth, some employees note that it can be difficult to advance within the company.

review_title: Would not recommend if fast processes and organization matter to you
pros: flexible unpaid time off / time off easy job many breaks available in your day to day
cons: horrible organization, too many changes with no proper communication to team, expected to meet metrics while leadership does not establish good enough relationships with team/ team members support. staff takes a long time to get back to team with questions. Subtle Ageism is real (they do not tell you, but they do treat people who are older like they are dumb) - > this is coming from a person in their 20s this is just what I have observed. other companies pay $30-34 an hour for same role/tasks.

pros: Opportunities for growth and development: Accenture offers its employees a variety of opportunities for professional development and career advancement. The company has a strong focus on employee training and development, which allows employees to build new skills and grow within the organization. Diverse and inclusive work environment: Accenture is known for its diverse and inclusive work environment, which values diversity in all its forms, including race, gender, sexual orientation, and culture. Competitive compensation: Accenture offers competitive salaries and benefits packages to its employees, including health insurance, retirement plans, and paid time off. Global exposure: Accenture is a global company with a presence in more than 120 countries, which offers employees the opportunity to work on projects and interact with colleagues from different parts of the world. Focus on innovation: Accenture is committed to innovation and staying ahead of the curve in the fast-paced world of technology and business. This focus on innovation creates an exciting and dynamic work environment for employees. Social responsibility: Accenture is committed to making a positive impact in the communities where it operates, and encourages its employees to get involved in charitable and volunteer initiatives.
cons: Long hours and demanding workload: Accenture is known for its fast-paced and demanding work environment, which can sometimes lead to long hours and a high workload for employees. Work-life balance: With a demanding workload and long hours, it can be challenging for Accenture employees to maintain a good work-life balance. Bureaucracy: As a large global company, Accenture can sometimes be affected by bureaucracy and red tape, which can slow down decision-making and progress.

review_title: Great Company for Career Growth and Learning Opportunities
job_title: App Automation Engineer Specialist in Chennai
pros: I have been working as a Senior Automation Engineer at Accenture for the past 4 years, and I must say that it has been an amazing journey so far. Accenture is a great company that provides endless opportunities to learn, grow and enhance your skills. The company culture is inclusive, and I have always felt supported by my colleagues and managers. One of the best things about working at Accenture is the opportunity to work on projects across different industries and with clients from around the world. As an Automation Engineer, I have worked on projects in the financial, healthcare and retail industries, which has broadened my understanding of business operations and technology. This has also helped me develop a diverse set of skills that I can apply to different projects. In addition to the work, Accenture also provides ample opportunities for training and upskilling. I have attended multiple training programs and webinars on the latest technologies and tools, which has helped me stay ahead of the curve in my field. The company also encourages its employees to pursue certifications, which further adds value to their careers.
cons: While Accenture offers competitive salaries and benefits, some employees may feel that their compensation is not commensurate with their experience or level of expertise.

pros: A lot of talented and passionate people work here. There are a wide variety of opportunities in different industries due to the size of the company, so it's easy to try various things, find your niche, and grow.
cons: The organization is very impersonal. You're subject to metrics and policies that are nonsensical at best and manipulative at worst. You're regularly expected to work 16 hour days, work during PTO, etc. Leadership gives lip service to work life balanace and diversity but doesn't practice it. Experienced lots of sexual harassment. Not a lot of structure/support for growth and further education, and a lot of politicking is expected/required. Folks at the junior levels will likely have to work on some very boring projects that aren't in their area of skill/interest in order to meet chargeability requirements.

review_title: Supportive, people-first environment but significantly less pay
pros: This company has a great culture, supportive people-first management with tons of resources for career advancement, certification, and growth. If you are not happy with your current office you can apply internally to other jobs all over the US and overseas. If you're "let go" from your current office they'll place you "on the bench" with pay until you can find another office to take you.
cons: Accenture knows it has a great culture and employee support so it can pay you significantly less than the competition. Since the type of work it conducts is mostly B2B and gov't contracts, it is constantly looking to cut costs to win bids. When asking for a raise it can be an immense struggle, almost like shopping for a car at a dealership.

pros: Accenture is a great place to challenge yourself and grow, whether you are an experienced hire or someone who is just starting their career. I have been a fresh-out-of-college analyst, a consultant, a rehire and a senior manager at this company and my experience is overall positive and I generally recommend it.
cons: This is less a con, and more just the nature of things. In the Consulting arm of the business the career progression can be cutthroat, sometimes opaque, and experiences at the firm can be very different from person to person. It is not for everyone, but it is great for certain people at certain times in their lives. I recommend talking to someone who works at Accenture candidly if you can.

review_title: Navigating the High-Pressure Culture of Accenture India: A Review of the Pros and Cons
pros: Career Advancement Opportunities: Accenture is a large, global company with many different career paths available for employees. This provides opportunities for employees to advance their careers and take on new roles within the company. Competitive Compensation: Accenture is known for offering competitive compensation packages to its employees, including salaries, bonuses, and benefits.
cons: Long working hours: One potential con of working at Accenture in India is that the company is known for having a demanding work culture, which can include long working hours. This can make it difficult to maintain a good work-life balance and can lead to burnout. High stress environment: Another potential con of working at Accenture in India is that the company's fast-paced and high-pressure work environment can be stressful. This may not be suitable for everyone, as it can lead to high levels of anxiety and can be detrimental to one's mental and physical health.

job_title: Application Development Senior Analyst in Bangalore
pros: Overall it's a good company compared to TCS, Infosys etc as it gives better package, security, better option for Women. They provide cab and shuttle facility. Also have good work environment and can find friendly colleagues. Can get shift allowance and other good benefits like benefits you and reward points in which we can convert that points into credit points in other apps like mayntra, book my show, lifestyle and many more apps in which accenture is collaborated. Have good hikes compared to other MNC's. And promotions depends on the performance of an individual. Accenture is not only into work, it also encourages employee's into other fun activities Aswell.
cons: Nothing as of now .

pros: Career growth: Accenture is a large, global company with a wide range of clients and projects. This can provide opportunities for employees to work on diverse projects and gain a wide range of skills and experience, which can help them to advance their careers. Training and development: Accenture places a strong emphasis on training and development for its employees. This can include both on-the-job training as well as formal training programs. Exposure to new technologies: Accenture works with many of the world's leading companies, and as a result, its employees have the opportunity to work with cutting-edge technologies and innovative approaches. Collaborative culture: Accenture is known for its collaborative culture, and employees are encouraged to work together to solve problems and share knowledge. Opportunities for international assignments: Accenture operates in more than 50 countries, and employees may have the opportunity to work on projects in different countries and gain international experience. Good compensation package, health benefits and perks.
cons: Long working hours: Accenture is known for its fast-paced and demanding work environment. Employees may be required to work long hours, including evenings and weekends, to meet tight deadlines and deliver results for clients. High stress levels: With fast-paced and demanding work environment, this can lead to high stress levels for employees. Limited autonomy: Accenture has a strong emphasis on teamwork and collaboration, which can be positive, but some employees may feel that they have limited autonomy to make decisions or take initiative. Rotation: Some employees may experience frequent rotation to different projects, which may make it difficult to settle in one place or in one team.

pros: Accenture truly does have some of the best people. The NY office is super cool and is set up to facilitate networking. There is always a happy hour of sorts and we have some pretty cool benefits. Constantly learning with building up your knowledge of technology
cons: As an analyst in Accenture, you are responsible for your career trajectory. You are the captain of your own ship. Your success is determined by who you know and how they advocate for you in performance achievement and finding a project. You are looking for a job within your job. There are tools to assist with that but they seldom help with staffing. Again, it is your network that will help you find your next project. If you're on the bench for too long, you will be terminated. (too long is determined on a case by case basis)

cons: 1. Work hours depend on the client's location so there is a possibility of working night shifts 2. Learning may be hampered depending on which tools your project uses but self-studying is key 3. Some projects have higher budget compared to others so promotion may be limited

pros: Working at Accenture has its perks. The company provides HMO, mental health support, and free medicine. Additionally, when you resign, they offer you a project or team switch that you may prefer. The managers are generally nice and considerate, especially Ms. Yve.
cons: I'd been working at Accenture for 14 months, and while there are some positives, such as gaining valuable experience, there are also some downsides. One of the main cons is the low salary (16,500 for transaction processing role), which can be challenging to live on. Additionally, overtime is often required, and it's mandatory to track it on an Excel sheet. This can lead to working long hours and can be quite draining. Finally, some of the quotas set by the company are difficult to achieve, which can be frustrating at times.

pros: Nice people, they pay overtime, and you can even change overtime when doing training or certifications
cons: No real control on what type of projects you will be placed on. Projects are often for very big clients so expect a lot of bureaucracy. 90% of new hires are females, so it can be difficult for males to be hired for entry level positions.

review_title: As we climb Cairngorm on the T-bar I ask my instructor Alistair if he can sum up the appeal of our Scottish slopes
pros: There are a lot of reasons why someone might want to become a front end developer: Money: The job pays well and has strong career prospects. Challenge: You get to work on a variety of interesting things. Impact: Front end development work is seen by everyone who interacts with a brand.
cons: Understand whom you're building for, Employ the right frameworks, and Organize your codebase.

pros: Brand name Variety of clients competitive salary Over all Accenture was the biggest learning experience for me in my life. I realised how career decisions should not be taken hastily and should always research well on the people culture of a firm.
cons: Racist colleagues- have worked for many global firms but at Accenture I felt racism for the first time. No empathy - I was let go on my birthday Colleagues are unhelpful Company with no value- my first interaction with a senior employee was -‘the career you chose is difficult and you should reconsider’ and this was him judging me for where I come from as I never worked with him before.

job_title: Application Development Specialist in Richardson, TX
pros: Work Life balance Opportunity to groom latest technology
cons: Career growth is not base don what you perform. Its based on the queue where the seniors in project would be lined up without getting promotion and you will get promoted only after them if at all any slots are available. Also most of the accounts have resources who are there working the account for atleast 7-8 years and will play all politics they want by creating dependencies. There is no resource shuffling which is not good for new hires to the project.

review_title: great clients, but have to be assertive moving around the firm.
pros: You'll get a great breadth of exposure and work here that will either launch your career in your industry of choice or prepare you to be a director within the firm. To get that experience though, you'll have to be the pilot of your own career. Don't be shy, speak out, and make sure you get recognized.
cons: Long work hours might not be for most - if you want a work-life balance, mention hours worked on average during your interview.

review_title: My first job in Finance department - pretty good evolution
job_title: Transaction Processing Associate in Bucharest, Bucuresti
pros: A community where I was able to both develop my own skills and bring added value to the team; Friendly co-workers and team-leads; You have the possibility to move thru teams and/or projects, to discover whether you like more Customer Service / Payroll, AP, AR or others; You can choose your career path - to become team leader or subject matter expert;
cons: The salary ranges are based on levels - eg level 12 is the lower one in Romania, so after an evaluation and based on company's needs, at some point you can be promoted to the next level - 11. For me, it took almost 3 years to be promoted, and the salary difference between level 12 and level 11 were small (20%).

review_title: Good place to start your career
job_title: Application Development Analyst in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: Accenture is a very strong starting place for your career, since it's highly recognised and respected on your resume. Furthermore, many of the senior developers I've worked with have been very good at their jobs, and I've learned a huge amount during my time here.
cons: First and foremost: extremely low pay for development roles (£28k vs receiving £40k offers) and absolutely no opportunity for a strong career. Accenture has a very 'corporate-cult' atmosphere, where the 'opportunity for growth' is considered a great perk of working for the company - at the expense of your salary. I fear that once you have accrued too many years under your belt at Accenture, it would become impossible for you to leave for greener pastures, so I wouldn't stay there too long.

review_title: Good stable company to be associated
pros: - Vast opportunities within company - Diversity Inclusion in every business that it does - Advanced technology and one of the first companies to attempt AI, RPA, Metaverse technologies and showcase - Employee engagement, benefits and perks are always matched with market benchmarking - Stable and reliable brand to work with.
cons: - Growth is slow in initial years of start. - Small fish in big ocean, competition is high

review_title: Do not join as a Direct Admit MD
pros: lots of smart people that want to do the best by their customers at L5 and below. resources there to help you learn and further your technical knowledge.
cons: Other MDs that have been there since they graduated College 25 years ago are very narrow minded and tend to fill up the room on every big deal, leaving new folks out in the cold. The world has moved past this old school way of selling and dealing with clients, yet those that are now SMDs don't/won't see it because they have never experienced the real world. They need to clean out those veterans and let some new hires do what they were hired to do - bring a fresh perspective. Too much red-tape to get a deal done. Too much sandbagging to keep deals off the New Business review radar.

review_title: Good place to work at - most important criterion is that one should upskill and clear exams in Techgenics
pros: I joined as a fresher in Accenture. Before joining Accenture, we were given 3 months' time to complete the trainings on one of the tracks assigned to us. I was assigned java Developer track. After completion of training, we were under Techgenics training for 6 months. I was assigned Cloud transformation domain. After completion of training was a part of Migration execution team and worked in pre and post migration tasks. Working here is good because the work culture is good and we get to reskill and upskill ourselves. We also get feedback from seniors and get to learn about our goals and objectives.
cons: Bench period. I was on bench for 3 months. During those 3 months, my registration for the subjects in techgenics training was not approved. We were given 6 months time to complete techgenics training. But i couldn't complete my training on time. Sometimes, due to project requirements, we had to place more priority to project than training. This is the second reason for constraints in completion of techgenics training. More amount of work when allocated to project and little to no work when on bench.

pros: Senior Software Engineer - Accenture November 2020 — August 2022 Cloud Native Automation System 5G Bengaluru, India • Created and documented over 140+API’s with Java SpringBoot microservices and Python Flask using MySQL and MongoDB as Database • Collaborated for Application Security Testing, making it SAST and DAST ready for production • Engineered RSA+AES Cryptography for safe end-to-end communication on Spring boot as well as Angular JS and ReactJS • Integrated Jenkins Pipeline with SpringBoot to fetch dynamic data as well as trigger pipelines by sending data to the pipeline • Implemented Vault functionality for additional security for secure storing of important credentials • Streamlined Dashboard elements for web and mobile analytics that consumed the API’s and KPI’s used to monitor real-time data from various cities using Angular JS and ReactJS
cons: High demands and long hours: Accenture is known for its fast-paced and demanding work environment, which may require long hours or tight deadlines at times. High pressure: Accenture's clients often have high expectations and deadlines, which can create a high-pressure work environment. Limited opportunities for advancement: As a large company, Accenture may have more limited opportunities for advancement compared to smaller firms.

review_title: Good place to start, but beware of limited opportunities
pros: Accenture is a large company a vast amount of resources, which can be taken advantage of further your career path and interests. There is a culture of collaboration, and people are generally happy to assist and combine efforts with regard to project work. Opportunity for travel and benefits.
cons: High rate of turnover of associates. Some people have left and returned several times. Leads to apathetic responses at some points, and can make it hard to build and maintain a strong network. Some projects require more time and effort than others, which may result in working late nights and weekends.

review_title: Accenture approaches are pro empolyees all the time.
pros: Their human Resources team is expert with taking good care of the current employees. There are a lot of loyal employees, I personally know, that are more than 10 years in service already. They are truly experts in the field they forefront.
cons: There are some projects that are more compensated and attended. Communications with the clients can definitely be tough, but I know that at some point in the future they will surely manage to be in control over the client-vendor business conversations.

job_title: Full Stack Developer in Washington, DC
pros: I love working at Accenture.
cons: Maybe a con, but you have to track your progress and the things that qualify you for promotion. Otherwise if your advocate doesn’t know much, becuase it’s a big project then you won’t get much and might be stuck.

pros: Remote work, no crazy over time.
cons:
Pay is too low (lower than 80% of peers), growing very difficult.  Constant company re-orgs make it nearly impossible to get promote or grow past your level because you keep getting moved laterally.

Full of management that are non-technical and don't know about what they are doing.  This leads to making uninformed and incoherent decisions.  They are not receptive to constructive criticism and suggestions on how to do things.  It's only their way.  Ideas have to come from them exclusively.

Company is invasive with your data.  For example, they require that you use your personal phone for work and they must manage it by installing a profile instead of providing you a company issued device.

cons: Big company, so a lot to learn. It can be a bit overwhelming but they do a great job of curating the content specifically designed for your role. Hard work can be stressful at times.

The alternative to that view may be that I may be giving them too much credit, and they dont really know whats going on. :-)

review_title: Good for stable tenure and long run
job_title: Cyber Security Delivery Lead in Pune
pros: 1. The company has good policies regarding their employees looking after them in case of any emergency or work environment. 2. There are mix reviews of people working in different projects, for some it could be hectic but for some its pretty stable depending on your client, manager and team. 3. pros: Paid NCLEX registration and review. Work from Home while undergoing self paced review. Required at least 1 day RTO per month. Signing bonus amd WFH reimbursement.
cons: If failed in NCLEX no salary increase, may be deployed to PHRN account or other. Bonus is once deployed is NOT a guarantee. RTO while on training for a project. If passed the NCLEX exam, plus 10K premium increase ONLY. BUILD passers salary is not aligned to USRN. Beware.

review_title: Advertised as ACCOUNT/PARTNER MANAGER In Job Postings
job_title: Inside Sales Account Representative in Mississauga, ON
pros: - Working at Accenture (hopefully) opens doors to move within the company and network with over 700k employees - Diversity-first organization - Managerial support and others in the company are willing to help and talk to you
cons: - Mandatory in-office at the moment and commute times can be very long - Scope of work for this role was unknown and still is, they will advertise this role as account/partner management for a client but it is 100% sales and cold calling - They advertised the role in 3 different job postings and then told everyone that they needed to complete training and they were not guaranteed for the role they applied for - Role can be misleading and internal job title creates difficulties in transferring/applying to other jobs - Role is based out of a sales/lead gen company that was acquired by Accenture, which makes it feel like you are not really part of the true Accenture community - Role is very stagnant with little to no growth opportunities

pros: Good salary Very vast training possibility A lot of different projects to work on High diversity

cons: Pays way less than competitors, there's a general lack of leadership across the wider company, and it's easy to feel lost in a giant bureaucracy.

review_title: Feeling pretty aimless in a big pool
pros: Accenture provides ample opportunity for you to train yourself on different technologies.
cons: You have these opportunities to learn many different technologies because Accenture has no benched resources then they do billable positions for them. So because of this, you end up spending weeks learning (or even becoming certified with a technology) only to be told "there's no jobs. do it again with this technology and we'll see if there's jobs". On top of that, no conversations have been had with me regarding an increase in pay now that i have certifications as the "level" i'm on doesn't allow for it. So you COULD be hired on as a Sys Admin for a project making $50k a year. So there's that...

pros: At Accenture you can find the best way to work part time and still be a strong contributer with a great career. There are very many options to have a work life balance.
cons: Accenture has all the theory right to be the best employer but should follow through even better with those ambitions

review_title: Good to Start as a fresher But don't stay for more the 3-4 years. And try to start with some good Development Projects
job_title: Software Development Engineer In Test (SDET) in Pune
