review_title: Great company culture and great projects
pros: Great company culture, really striving to live its values. Rotated to new IT technologies in a very short time back in 2017-2018 - just check the stocks how well Accenture made it happen. I got a plenty of trust on large IT implementation from my early years there, learned a ton of things and got crazy amount of experience. Also, when Accenture makes a promise to deliver a project, they make it happen. In addition, Accenture doesn't have its own "Sales team" (like IBM, for example) - as an Manager (or Delivery lead), you pitch and sell the project to customer and if you win - you deliver it. So Accenture makes sure you sell the value and projects that are feasible and can make difference. I am proud for my time there.
cons: Not necessarily a con - but prepare for the steep learning curve and hard work.

Even after a year of experience they would blindly reject applications (in my core field) minutes after submission. This is just another BPO kind of job and will keep hiring knowing that there is endless supply of immigrant human labor.

review_title: The worst big company I've ever worked.
job_title: Content Moderator in Lisbon, Lisbon District
pros: Make sure you never work in Accenture's operation Lisbon.
cons: I've worked for several large companies and I can say Accenture was the worst. The company is completely MESS, there is no career monitoring, they make all the wrong payments and you are always getting paid one month within another (in case you notice that you were paid wrong), No doubt the worst structure to work: irregular lights ( very strong), precarious installations as elevators, bathrooms, air conditioning or heaters (doesn't exist), broken computers, meeting rooms that don't work, "we care" section room that you can't stand to stay inside because it's super hot and even the psychologists themselves they complain, not to mention that zero privacy to have a good conversation, zero lazer area, machines to buy food that don't work (and believe me, you miss it a lot when you work until 1 am), buses are always late and the worst quality service and conditions. And just to finish, it took me 1 month to receive my final bills which should have been paid on the last day of work according to Portuguese law. And not only did they pay me late, they made me exchange 30 emails with different people to finally correct everything that was wrong with my final payment and then they still didn't pay me for my scorecard.

In certain areas of the business, good talent can be underpaid. Learned this when they are willing to give you a 30%+ immediate increase when you are handing in that resignation.

Accenture provides transportation facility but the process to get one is so lengthy and no proper guidance is given. Hikes and promotions are so slow. They do some increment in your salary but that's almost negligible. review_title: It's a good place to work
job_title: Application Development Specialist in Long Beach, CA
pros: So many, many, many opportunities. If you don't like where you are or what you're doing in the company, you really have options. A lot of options. The culture seems to be one of "always looking forward" as they are always communicating the need to advance in your career. They offer many training opportunities to keep your skill up to date. They offer programs for professional development that help with your growth. The people I've worked with also are generally happy about being in the company as well. It's really a good place to be.
cons: As mentioned above, they really put a priority on personal growth. So expect to be training and collecting certifications related to your area of expertise, constantly. If you're a person that likes where you may be in your career and prefer to be a competent specialist in that realm, that's nice, but they seriously want growth. If you're more of an "I'm an expert in this field and wish to provide expert service here in this realm", you may get annoyed by the constant push to move up. review_title: Best place to learn how to work
pros: Your working for a large corporation, you process your own time sheet. You get lots of tech leadership process international standards training. You have a budget for team building. You get into different projects, you get to interact with an international team. Travel overseas? Maybe or not. Follow the procedures process because most admin tasks will be completed by you. This allows them to employ less admin people. Everybody got a team lead. Your job objective performance objectives are well defined, and the list is endless.
cons: Too much tech admin training compliance task to do. It fills your whole day or else?! Your TL will chase you endlessly. The chasing will reach the top org ladder barking at you. Ive had 7 years work there. I thinks thats enough..learn all you can while you can. When you leave there so much to put on your resume that the potential companies will benefit. Accenture will make the most out of you. Make sure you do the same.

review_title: Too much overhead for too little support
pros: Plenty of "clubs" to join - but you are expected to work during your lunch or overtime if you participate in them. Benefits are good - but worse than what we had prior to acquisition
cons: Too much overhead with little benefits to clients or employees. - Videos and productions for all meetings that are over the top and internal only. - Accounts receivable is non-existant - they have consultants and PMs, review, and send invoices to clients. We also manage the days outstanding. While we are supposed to support and maintain good customer service, we are also the "bad guys" pushing to get paid and nagging client. Too many emails about "office activities" and "participation" when we are expected to be fully billable too. Would love to participate with others, but I have to see my family and refuse to work my evenings so I can be viewed as a "team player" by senior management. We were acquired - so lost a lot of great benefits and gained so many more job duties and responsibilities without any reduction in already heavy workload. We lost our ability to meet and participate with our teams in person. No longer feel like part of the team I work with because supposed to be pushed into my regional office who does not have anyone doing the same type of work as I do or same clients.

pros: 1. Competitive salary and benefits: Accenture offers competitive salaries and benefits packages to its employees. This includes health insurance, retirement plans, and other perks. 2. Flexible work hours: Accenture offers flexible work hours, allowing employees to work when it is most convenient for them. 3. Professional development: Accenture provides employees with the opportunity to develop their skills and knowledge through training and development programs. 4. Global presence: Accenture has offices in more than 120 countries, giving employees the opportunity to work in different countries and gain international experience.
cons: 1. Long Hours: Accenture is known for its long hours, which can be difficult to manage if you have a family or other commitments outside of work. 2. High Stress: Accenture is a fast-paced environment and can be quite stressful at times. 3. Limited Career Progression: Accenture is a large company and it can be difficult to move up the ranks quickly. 4. Low Pay: Accenture is known for paying lower salaries than other consulting firms.

pros:
- Colleagues are often pleasant, young, motivated individuals 
- Great company events 
- Work/life balance is ok in technical consulting
cons:
- Pay in Accenture Technology is (too) low 
- In Accenture Technology moving up the career ladder on average takes longer than expected/ represented (I would guess people become manager on average after 8-10 yrs in Technology instead of the expected 4-5 if they start at analyst level). There are exceptions who fast track, but for every exception there are maybe 10 others who take much longer. 
- In technology consulting projects are typically longer (this is expected), but if they are understaffed on a project you're sometimes forced to work for a long time on a project that doesn't interest you (nor your colleagues). If so, you need to have the luck that your career counselor has enough pull to get you off the project or your manager supports your in one way or another, which wasn't the case for me (and cannot be the case for everyone, as they sold the project and need staffing). 
- My role in the project was technically uninteresting and made use of old technologies.

review_title: 3 years recap of working as an employee for Accenture
pros: Benefits: 401K, great health care, option to work remote, disability accommodations.
cons: Accenture is a massive corporation, so there is very little personalization amongst co-workers. While Accenture claims to help individuals succeed, they actually prioritize newer hires rather than investing in their associates. I've been working at Accenture for over 3 years, and despite being one of the top 10 agents in quality, I have yet to be promoted. Breaks depend on the project (i.e. working a higher risk project allots way more breaks than a lower risk project), but the times are inconsistent.
